articles.title: About this site
articles.description: Some additional details about the website

articles.title: Chemical Basis of Life
articles.description: A new article created to explain some key concepts in the unit, Chemical Basis of Life
articles.contents:
Introduction
At its most fundamental level, life is made up of matter. Matter is any substance that occupies space and has mass. Elements are unique forms of matter with specific chemical and physical properties that cannot break down into smaller substances by ordinary chemical reactions. There are 118 elements, but only 98 occur naturally. The remaining elements are unstable and require scientists to synthesize them in laboratories (ref. https://opened.cuny.edu/courseware/lesson/608/overview)

articles.title: Biodiversity
articles.description: A new article created explaining some key concepts of biodiversity
articles.contents:
Introduction to Biodiversity
Definition
The term biodiversity (from “biological diversity”) refers to the variety of life on Earth at all its levels, from genes to ecosystems, and can encompass the evolutionary, ecological, and cultural processes that sustain life. (ref.https://www.amnh.org/)

articles.title: Biomimicry
articles.description: A new article created to explain some key concepts of biomimicry and how its principle could be inspired to develop green innovation.
articles.contents:
Introduction
Humanity faces many challenges. Nature holds
solutions. Use the search function in the upper right of this page, or explore featured content below to discover examples of how we can learn from other species’ successful strategies and adaptations (asknature.org).

articles.title: Pongprapan Pongsophon
articles.contents:
Home

              Pongprapan Pongsophon
            
            
              
                
                    
                      
                         GitHub
                      
                    
                  
                                    
                    
                      
                         Email
                      
                    
                  
                                  
            
          
        
        
        
          
            
            Bio
            Pongprapan Pongsophon or shortly, Pong is an associate
            professor of science education at Kasetsart University,
            Bangkok, Thailand. He has been working there since 2006. At
            Kasetsart, he has taught science education courses at
            bachelor and graduate levels. He uses R programming on a
            daily basis, mostly for data manipulation and analysis. He
            has been studying other R’s functionality such as here using
            r to create a website. Pong is interested in the application
            of structural equation modeling in science education
            research. He is a dog and cat lover. In his free time, he is
            usually found at a cozy cafe in Bangkok reading a newspaper
            and get himself updated and relaxed.
            
            
            Education
            Kasetsart University | Bangkok
            Thailand
            Ph.D. in Science Education | in 2005
            Chulalongkorn University | Bangkok,
            Thailand
            B.Ed. in Secondary Science Teaching (Biology and General
            Science) 1st class honor | in 2000
            
            
            Experience
            Post-doctoral training  | University of
            Arkansas, USA |
            Post-doctoral training | University of
            Missouri at Columbia, USA |
            
            
            Selected publication
            Anantanukulwong, R., Pongsophon, P., Chiangga, S., Tan,
            A. (2023). Exploring students’ perceptions of learning
            equilibrium concepts through making Bulan kites. Physics
            Education, 58(1) id.015027, 13 pp.
            Anantanukulwong, R., Chiangga, S., Pongsophon, P., Tan,
            A. (2022). Enhancing Students’ Learning of the Concept of
            Equilibrium Through a Culturally Responsive Inquiry of the
            Bulan Kite. Science & Education.
            https://doi.org/10.1007/s11191-022-00398-0
            Pongsophon, P. & Herman, B. (2017). A theory of
            planned behaviour-based analysis of TIMSS 2011 to determine
            factors influencing inquiry teaching practices in
            high-performing countries. International Journal of Science
            Education. 39 (10), 1304-1325
            (DOI:10.1080/09500693.2017.1328620).

articles.title: Nature of Science
articles.description: Tenets of the nature of science
articles.contents:
Contents
The tentative nature of scientific knowledge
The empirical nature of science
The inferential, imaginative and creative nature of science
The subjective and theory-laden nature of science
The socially and culturally embedded nature of science
